title: 114_s385
content: The Act is titled the "Biennial Appropriations Act" and it revises the timetable outlined in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The Biennial Appropriations Act revises the timetable for budget-related actions, including submission deadlines for the President's budget, reports to Budget Committees, and completion of actions on the budget by Congress. The Biennial Appropriations Act sets deadlines for budget-related actions, including completion of reconciliation legislation by June 15 and House action on biennial appropriation bills by June 30. On August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill. On October 1, the fiscal year begins. In the case of the first session of Congress following a leap year and the start of a new President's term, specific dates will override the usual schedule. The schedule for budget-related actions includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports from the Congressional Budget Office, committee submissions, and Congress completing action on the budget resolution. The House completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill by July 20, with Congress finalizing the process by August 1. The defense appropriation bill is considered each year, along with reconciliation legislation, starting on October 1 when the fiscal year begins. In odd-numbered years, Congress shall enact an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Financial Services, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Environment, and Labor, Health and Human Services, Education. In even-numbered years, Congress shall consider and enact annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water. In even-numbered years, Congress shall consider and enact annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water, Homeland Security, Legislative Branch, and State-Foreign Operations. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET AND IMPOUNDMENT CONTROL ACT OF 1974. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to define "biennium" as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Committee allocations are also adjusted to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. The amendments involve adjustments to subsections (b) and (f)(2)(A) of the Act. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 31, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code includes defining 'biennium' and adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following 4 fiscal years. Amendment to Title 31, United States Code includes adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following 4 fiscal years. This involves changes in receipts and balance statements for each fiscal year in the biennium. The United States Code is amended to change references from "the fiscal year" to "each fiscal year in the biennium" in various sections related to functions, activities, and allowances in Title 31. The United States Code is amended to change references from "the fiscal year" to "each fiscal year in the biennium" in various sections related to functions, activities, and allowances in Title 31, including allowances for uncontrolled expenditures, tax expenditures, and future years. The United States Code is amended to change references from "the fiscal year" to "each fiscal year in the biennium" in various sections related to functions, activities, and allowances in Title 31. The United States Code is amended to update references from "the prior fiscal year" to "each of the 2 most recently completed fiscal years" in sections related to outlays and receipts in Title 31. The United States Code is amended to update references from "the prior fiscal year" to "each of the 2 most recently completed fiscal years" in sections related to outlays and receipts in Title 31. Additionally, estimated expenditures of the Legislative and Judicial Branches are now required to be reported every even-numbered year instead of annually. Section 1105(b) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to require reporting every even-numbered year instead of annually. Section 1105(c) is also amended to update references for each fiscal year in the biennium. The amendment updates reporting requirements to occur every even-numbered year instead of annually and adjusts references to fiscal years in the biennium for capital investment analysis. SEC. 5. TWO-YEAR APPROPRIATIONS; TITLE AND STYLE OF APPROPRIATIONS ACTS. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code is amended to specify the title and style of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. The style and title of Acts for defense appropriations shall be specified as 'An Act making appropriations for defense for fiscal year (insert fiscal year)', with amounts specified for each fiscal year. The term 'biennium' is defined in this section. The term 'biennium' is defined as in the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. Acts described in subsection (a)(1) are considered as provided in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. A technical and conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 2 of title 1, United States Code. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years unless the project will be completed with the provided funds. It also delays authorization or revenue bills until the budget resolution and all appropriations bills are completed. The joint resolution states that all appropriations bills will be considered after Congress completes action on the budget resolution. Certain exceptions apply in the Senate, such as defense measures and privileged considerations. Amendment to Table of Contents: The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended by adding a new section after section 315. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT. In each year without required funding, the House and Senate committees must hold a joint oversight hearing with the Appropriations Committee to review agency missions, the impact of biennial budgeting on efficiency, and cost savings. The agency's mission, impact of biennial budgeting on efficiency, cost savings, new programs, and terminated programs in the off year of the budget are reviewed in joint oversight hearings. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will assess the feasibility of transitioning to a 2-year fiscal period with a biennial budget process and submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on the Budget within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act and its amendments will take effect on January 1, 2016, applying to budget resolutions and appropriations for the biennium starting from fiscal year 2017.
